questions.prompt: How are elements arranged in the periodic table?
correctAnswers: in order of atomic number so that elements with similar properties are in groups
ordered by atomic number with similar properties in groups

feedback.correct: Perfect! Elements are arranged by atomic number, which groups similar elements together.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Elements aren't in mass order - hydrogen (1) comes before helium (4), but lithium (7) comes before beryllium (9). What number ARE they in order of?

revisionFacts: Elements are arranged in order of atomic number.
Elements with similar properties are in the same group (vertical column).
This arrangement creates repeating patterns - hence 'periodic'.

questions.prompt: Why is the periodic table called 'periodic'?
correctAnswers: similar properties occur at regular intervals

feedback.correct: Exactly right! 'Periodic' means repeating at regular intervals.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Think about the word 'periodic' - like a periodic table in maths, or a periodic wave. What does periodic mean?

revisionFacts: Periodic means occurring at regular intervals.
Similar chemical properties repeat as you go across periods.
This pattern was the key discovery that made the periodic table work.

questions.prompt: What does the group number tell us about an element?

feedback.correct: Spot on! Group number = number of outer shell electrons (for most groups).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Look at Group 1 - they all have 1 electron in common. What do you think that electron is?

revisionFacts: Group number = number of outer shell electrons (for groups 1-7).
Elements in the same group have similar chemical properties.
This is because they have the same number of outer electrons.

questions.prompt: What does the period number tell us about an element?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Period number = number of electron shells.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Draw out sodium (Period 3) and lithium (Period 2). What's different about their structure?

revisionFacts: Period number = number of electron shells.
Period 1 has 1 shell, Period 2 has 2 shells, etc.
This determines the size of the atom.

questions.prompt: How did Mendeleev overcome the problems of earlier periodic tables?
correctAnswers: by leaving gaps for elements not yet discovered
left gaps for elements he thought had not been discovered

feedback.correct: Brilliant! Mendeleev's genius was leaving gaps for elements that fit the pattern.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Mendeleev was bold - when his pattern didn't work, he assumed elements were missing. What did he do about those missing spots?

revisionFacts: Mendeleev left gaps for undiscovered elements.
He also changed the order in some places to match properties.
His predictions were later proven correct when new elements were found.

questions.prompt: What is an ion?
correctAnswers: an atom that has lost or gained electrons
an atom which has lost or gained an electron to become electrically charged
atom that has lost or gained electrons and is charged

feedback.correct: Exactly! Ions are atoms that have become charged by losing or gaining electrons.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! An atom normally has equal protons (+) and electrons (-). What happens when this balance changes?

revisionFacts: Ion = charged atom (has lost or gained electrons).
Positive ions have lost electrons.
Negative ions have gained electrons.

questions.prompt: What type of ions do metals form?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Metals lose electrons to form positive ions (cations).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Metals sit on the left of the periodic table and lose electrons easily. When you lose negative charges, what charge are you left with?

revisionFacts: Metals form positive ions (cations).
They do this by losing outer shell electrons.
More reactive metals lose electrons more easily.

questions.prompt: What is oxidation in terms of electrons?

feedback.correct: Perfect! OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss (of electrons).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Think: OIL RIG. What does the OIL stand for?

revisionFacts: Oxidation = loss of electrons.
Use OILRIG to remember: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain.
When metals react, they are oxidised (lose electrons).

questions.prompt: What is reduction in terms of electrons?

feedback.correct: Perfect! OILRIG: Reduction Is Gain (of electrons).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Think: OIL RIG. What does the RIG stand for?

revisionFacts: Reduction = gain of electrons.
Use OILRIG to remember: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain.
When metal ions become metals, they are reduced (gain electrons).

questions.prompt: What type of ions do non-metals form?

feedback.correct: Yes! Non-metals gain electrons to form negative ions (anions).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Non-metals sit on the right and want to gain electrons. When you gain negative charges, what overall charge do you have?

revisionFacts: Non-metals form negative ions (anions).
They do this by gaining electrons.
Group 7 elements gain 1 electron to become -1 ions.

questions.prompt: Why are Group 0 elements called noble gases?
correctAnswers: they have a complete outer shell
they have a full outer shell and are inert

feedback.correct: Exactly! Full outer shells make them stable and unreactive (noble/inert).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Count the outer electrons: He has 2, Ne has 8, Ar has 8. What's special about these numbers?

revisionFacts: Noble gases have full outer electron shells.
Helium has 2 outer electrons, the rest have 8.
Full shells make them very unreactive (inert).

questions.prompt: What does 'inert' mean?

feedback.correct: Correct! Inert = unreactive.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Think about the noble gases - do they react with other elements easily or not at all?

revisionFacts: Inert means unreactive.
Noble gases are inert because they have full outer shells.
They don't need to lose or gain electrons.

questions.prompt: What is the name of the Group 1 elements?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Group 1 = alkali metals.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! When Group 1 metals react with water, they make hydroxides (like NaOH). Solutions of hydroxides are alkaline. So we call Group 1...

revisionFacts: Group 1 elements are called alkali metals.
They all have 1 outer shell electron.
They form alkaline solutions with water (metal hydroxides).

questions.prompt: What products are formed when Group 1 metals react with water?

feedback.correct: Spot on! Metal + water → metal hydroxide + hydrogen.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! When sodium reacts with water, you see fizzing (a gas) and the solution goes alkaline (a base). What gas gives a squeaky pop?

revisionFacts: Group 1 + water → metal hydroxide + hydrogen.
The solution becomes alkaline (pH > 7).
Hydrogen gas is produced (squeaky pop test).

questions.prompt: Write the general word equation for Group 1 metals reacting with water:

feedback.correct: Perfect word equation!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! The products are metal hydroxide (like NaOH) + a gas that tests with squeaky pop. Complete: Metal + water → ...

revisionFacts: General equation: Metal + water → metal hydroxide + hydrogen
Example: 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂
The metal hydroxide dissolves to make alkaline solution.

questions.prompt: Write the balanced symbol equation for Group 1 metals reacting with water (use M for metal):

feedback.correct: Excellent! Perfect balancing.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Count the H atoms: 2 in H₂O on left, but we need 2 in H₂ on right AND some in MOH. How many M and H₂O do we need?

revisionFacts: Balanced: 2M + 2H₂O → 2MOH + H₂
The 2s balance the hydrogen atoms.
For sodium: 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂

questions.prompt: What unique observation do you see when lithium reacts with water?

feedback.correct: Yes! Lithium is the least reactive - it fizzes gently and doesn't melt.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Li is the LEAST reactive. Compare it to Na which melts and K which burns. What does Li do differently?

revisionFacts: Lithium fizzes gently and doesn't melt.
It's the least reactive of Li, Na, K.
It moves slowly on the water surface.

questions.prompt: What unique observation do you see when sodium reacts with water?

feedback.correct: Perfect! The heat from the reaction melts sodium into a ball.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! The reaction releases heat. Na's melting point is 98°C. What happens to sodium metal when it gets that hot?

revisionFacts: Sodium melts into a ball (melting point 98°C).
It fizzes more vigorously than lithium.
More reactive than Li, less reactive than K.

questions.prompt: What unique observation do you see when potassium reacts with water?
correctAnswers: it burns with a lilac flame
melts and burns with lilac flame

feedback.correct: Excellent! The hydrogen ignites, giving a lilac/purple flame.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! K is SO reactive the hydrogen catches fire. Metal flames have specific colours - what colour flame does potassium give?

revisionFacts: Potassium reacts so vigorously the hydrogen ignites.
Lilac/purple flame is characteristic of potassium.
Most reactive of the first three Group 1 metals.

questions.prompt: Order these Group 1 metals from LEAST to MOST reactive:

feedback.correct: Perfect! Reactivity increases DOWN Group 1.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! As you go DOWN Group 1 (Li → Na → K), reactivity increases. Which is at the top?

revisionFacts: Group 1 reactivity: Li < Na < K < Rb < Cs
Reactivity increases down the group.
Outer electron gets further from nucleus = easier to lose.

questions.prompt: Why do Group 1 metals become more reactive going down the group?
correctAnswers: outer electron is further from nucleus
outer shell electron is further from the nucleus
outer electron further away from nucleus
less attraction between electron and nucleus

feedback.correct: Spot on! More shells = weaker attraction to outer electron.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Compare Li (2 shells) with K (4 shells). Which one has its outer electron further from the nucleus? Is it easier or harder to remove?

revisionFacts: More electron shells = outer electron further from nucleus.
Weaker attraction = easier to lose outer electron.
Easier to lose electron = more reactive metal.

questions.prompt: What is the name of the Group 7 elements?

feedback.correct: Correct! Group 7 = halogens.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! They all have 7 outer electrons. Fluo-, Chloro-, Bromo-, Iodo-... what's the pattern in their names?

revisionFacts: Group 7 elements are called halogens.
They all have 7 outer shell electrons.
Examples: fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine.

questions.prompt: Order these halogens from LEAST to MOST reactive:

feedback.correct: Perfect! Halogen reactivity DECREASES down the group.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Unlike Group 1, Group 7 reactivity DECREASES down the group. Fluorine is at the top - is it most or least reactive?

revisionFacts: Halogen reactivity: F > Cl > Br > I
Reactivity decreases down Group 7 (opposite to Group 1!).
Harder to gain electron as outer shell gets further from nucleus.

questions.prompt: Write a word equation for chlorine displacing bromine from sodium bromide:
correctAnswers: chlorine + sodium bromide → bromine + sodium chloride
chlorine + sodium bromide --> bromine + sodium chloride
chlorine + sodium bromide -> sodium chloride + bromine

feedback.correct: Perfect! More reactive chlorine displaces less reactive bromine.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Chlorine is above bromine in Group 7, so more reactive. Can Cl kick Br out of its compound?

revisionFacts: More reactive halogens displace less reactive ones.
Cl₂ + 2NaBr → Br₂ + 2NaCl
Solution would turn from colourless to orange/brown (bromine).

questions.prompt: Put these elements in order from MOST to LEAST reactive:

feedback.correct: Excellent knowledge of the reactivity series!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Use the mnemonic: Please Stop Calling Me A Careless Zebra, Instead Call Me A Solid Gold. Where does each metal go?

revisionFacts: Full series: K, Na, Li, Ca, Mg, (C), Zn, Fe, (H), Cu, Ag, Au
Carbon and hydrogen are non-metals but included for reference.
Metals above carbon need electrolysis to extract.

questions.prompt: Write the general word equation for a metal reacting with oxygen:

feedback.correct: Perfect! Combustion of metals produces oxides.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! When magnesium burns in oxygen, it forms magnesium oxide (MgO). What's the pattern?

revisionFacts: Metal + oxygen → metal oxide
This is an oxidation reaction (metal gains oxygen).
Example: 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO

questions.prompt: Why is the reaction of metal with oxygen called 'oxidation'?

feedback.correct: Yes! Oxidation = gain of oxygen (in oxygen-transfer terms).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Look at the name 'oxidation' - what element is in that word? Does the metal gain or lose that element?

revisionFacts: Oxidation (oxygen-transfer) = gain of oxygen.
Oxidation (electron-transfer) = loss of electrons.
Both definitions describe the same process from different perspectives.

questions.prompt: Write the general word equation for a metal reacting with acid:

rejectFeedback.salt + water: I can see why you'd think that - it's a common mix-up. But remember: metals + acids produce hydrogen gas (test with lit splint for squeaky pop), while neutralisation reactions produce water.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Metal + acid → salt + hydrogen (NOT water!).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Drop Mg into HCl - you get fizzing (a gas) and a solution left behind (salt). What gas squeaks with a lit splint?

revisionFacts: Metal + acid → salt + hydrogen
Only metals above hydrogen in reactivity series react.
The gas produced is hydrogen, NOT water.

questions.prompt: Describe the test for hydrogen gas:

rejectFeedback.glowing splint: I can see why you might think that. That's the oxygen test. Hydrogen needs a LIT splint (with flame).

feedback.correct: Perfect! Hydrogen + oxygen → water (explosive reaction = squeaky pop).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! We use a BURNING splint (lit, with flame). What sound does hydrogen + oxygen make when they react?

revisionFacts: Hydrogen test: lit splint → squeaky pop.
Hydrogen burns rapidly in air (explosive).
Don't confuse with oxygen test (relights glowing splint).

questions.prompt: Which metals do NOT react with dilute acids? (Select all that apply)

feedback.correct: Correct! Metals below hydrogen don't react with acids.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Look at the reactivity series. Only metals ABOVE hydrogen react with acids. Which are below?

revisionFacts: Only metals above hydrogen react with dilute acids.
Copper, silver, and gold are below hydrogen - no reaction.
Magnesium and zinc are above hydrogen - they react vigorously.

questions.prompt: What is a metal displacement reaction?
correctAnswers: more reactive metal takes place of less reactive metal
a more reactive metal replaces a less reactive metal from its salt
more reactive metal displaces less reactive metal from compound

feedback.correct: Excellent! The reactivity series predicts displacement reactions.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Imagine a boxing match - which metal is stronger (more reactive) and can kick out the weaker one?

revisionFacts: More reactive metal displaces less reactive metal from compound.
Example: Zn + CuSO₄ → ZnSO₄ + Cu
No reaction if the metal is less reactive than the one in the compound.

questions.prompt: Write the word equation for zinc reacting with iron chloride:
correctAnswers: zinc + iron chloride → zinc chloride + iron
zinc + iron chloride --> zinc chloride + iron
zinc + iron chloride -> iron + zinc chloride

rejectFeedback.iron chloride + zinc: Good thinking about the reactants. But in displacement, the metals swap places. The more reactive metal takes the non-metal from the compound.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Zinc is more reactive, so displaces iron.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Check the reactivity series: is Zn above or below Fe? The higher one 'steals' the chloride.

revisionFacts: Zinc + iron chloride → zinc chloride + iron
Zinc is more reactive than iron.
The more reactive metal takes the non-metal.

questions.prompt: What is a spectator ion?
correctAnswers: ion that doesn't change in a reaction

feedback.correct: Exactly! Spectator ions are present but don't participate.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! In Ca + MgSO₄ → CaSO₄ + Mg, the SO₄²⁻ appears on both sides unchanged. What do we call ions that just 'watch'?

revisionFacts: Spectator ions don't change during reaction.
They appear unchanged on both sides of equation.
Omit them in ionic equations to show actual change.

questions.prompt: What is an ionic equation?
correctAnswers: equation showing only ions that change

feedback.correct: Perfect! Ionic equations show only the ions that actually react.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! If SO₄²⁻ doesn't change, why write it twice? What type of equation leaves out the 'spectator' ions?

revisionFacts: Ionic equation = balanced equation without spectator ions.
Shows only the species that actually change.
Makes it easier to see what's really happening.

questions.prompt: What is an ore?
correctAnswers: metal combined with other elements in rock
a metal combined with other elements found in rock

feedback.correct: Yes! Ores contain metal compounds that can be extracted.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! We dig up rock containing iron oxide (Fe₂O₃). What do we call this useful rock that contains metal compounds?

revisionFacts: Ore = rock containing metal compound.
Most metals exist as compounds (usually oxides).
We extract pure metal from the ore.

questions.prompt: What does 'native' mean for metals?
correctAnswers: found as pure metal not combined with other elements

feedback.correct: Perfect! Native metals are unreactive enough to exist uncombined.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Gold is so unreactive we find it as pure Au, not combined. What word describes 'found naturally as an element'?

revisionFacts: Native = found as pure element, not combined.
Only very unreactive metals are found native.
Examples: gold, silver, sometimes copper.

questions.prompt: In metal extraction, what does 'reduction' mean?

feedback.correct: Exactly! Reduction = loss of oxygen (from the ore).
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Iron oxide (Fe₂O₃) becomes iron (Fe). What has the oxygen done - been gained or lost?

revisionFacts: Reduction (oxygen-transfer) = loss of oxygen.
Metal ore is reduced to extract pure metal.
Example: Fe₂O₃ → Fe (iron oxide loses oxygen)

questions.prompt: Why is carbon used to reduce metal oxides?
correctAnswers: it is more reactive than the metal
more reactive than the metal being extracted

feedback.correct: Yes! Carbon must be more reactive to 'steal' the oxygen.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! For carbon to remove oxygen from iron oxide, carbon must 'want' oxygen more than iron does. Where is carbon in the reactivity series?

revisionFacts: Carbon must be more reactive than the metal to reduce it.
Carbon removes oxygen from metal oxide.
Only works for metals below carbon in reactivity series.

questions.prompt: What is electrolysis?
correctAnswers: using electricity to split a compound

feedback.correct: Perfect! Electrolysis = using electricity to split compounds.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Think about the words: electro = electricity, lysis = breaking/splitting. What does electrolysis do?

revisionFacts: Electrolysis = breaking down compound with electricity.
Used to extract reactive metals (above carbon).
Requires molten or dissolved ionic compound.

questions.prompt: When is electrolysis used for metal extraction?
correctAnswers: for metals above carbon in reactivity series
when metal is more reactive than carbon

feedback.correct: Spot on! Carbon can't reduce more reactive metals.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Carbon can't take oxygen from very reactive metal oxides. Which metals are MORE reactive than carbon?

revisionFacts: Electrolysis for metals MORE reactive than carbon.
Includes: K, Na, Li, Ca, Mg, Al.
Carbon reduction doesn't work for these.

questions.prompt: What is the main disadvantage of electrolysis?
correctAnswers: expensive due to high energy costs
uses large amount of electrical energy

feedback.correct: Yes! Continuous electricity supply is very expensive.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Electrolysis needs constant electrical current - think about your electricity bill. Is this cheap or expensive?

revisionFacts: Electrolysis is expensive - needs continuous electricity.
This is why aluminium used to be very costly.
Carbon reduction is much cheaper when it works.

questions.prompt: What are the three key steps in preparing a salt from metal and acid?
correctAnswers: excess metal to acid, filter, crystallise
add excess metal until stops fizzing, filter off unreacted metal, evaporate water

feedback.correct: Perfect! Those are the three essential steps.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Think: (1) make sure all acid reacts, (2) remove solid metal, (3) get solid salt crystals. What are the 3 steps?

revisionFacts: Step 1: Add excess metal until fizzing stops.
Step 2: Filter to remove unreacted metal.
Step 3: Evaporate water to get salt crystals.

questions.prompt: Write the general word equation for acid reacting with alkali (or base):

feedback.correct: Perfect neutralisation equation!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Acid + alkali makes the pH go to 7 (neutral). What two products form when we neutralise an acid?

revisionFacts: Acid + alkali (or base) → salt + water
This is a neutralisation reaction.
pH moves towards 7.

questions.prompt: Write the general word equation for acid reacting with metal carbonate:
correctAnswers: acid + metal carbonate → salt + water + carbon dioxide
acid + metal carbonate --> salt + water + carbon dioxide
acid + metal carbonate -> salt + water + CO2

feedback.correct: Excellent! Don't forget the carbon dioxide!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Acid + CaCO₃ gives fizzing (gas) + liquid left behind. You get salt + water + which gas turns limewater milky?

revisionFacts: Acid + metal carbonate → salt + water + CO₂
Carbon dioxide turns limewater milky.
Fizzing shows CO₂ being released.

questions.prompt: What is an acid in terms of ions?
correctAnswers: substance that forms H+ ions in water

feedback.correct: Perfect! Acids produce H⁺ ions in solution.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! HCl in water splits into H⁺ and Cl⁻. What ion do all acids release?

revisionFacts: Acid = substance that forms H⁺ ions in water.
Higher H⁺ concentration = lower pH.
Strong acids ionise completely.

questions.prompt: What is an alkali in terms of ions?
correctAnswers: substance that forms OH- ions in water

feedback.correct: Yes! Alkalis produce OH⁻ (hydroxide) ions.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! NaOH in water splits into Na⁺ and OH⁻. What ion do all alkalis release?

revisionFacts: Alkali = substance that forms OH⁻ ions in water.
Alkalis are soluble bases.
Higher OH⁻ concentration = higher pH.

questions.prompt: Write the ionic equation for all neutralisation reactions:

feedback.correct: Perfect! This is the fundamental neutralisation equation.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Acid releases H⁺, alkali releases OH⁻. What do these combine to make?

revisionFacts: Universal ionic equation: H⁺(aq) + OH⁻(aq) → H₂O(l)
This happens in every neutralisation.
The salt's ions are spectators.

questions.prompt: What is a strong acid?
correctAnswers: acid that completely ionises to form H+ ions

feedback.correct: Yes! Strong acids ionise completely.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! In strong acids, ALL HCl molecules split into H⁺ and Cl⁻ ions. What percentage ionises - some or all?

revisionFacts: Strong acid = completely ionises in water.
Examples: HCl, HNO₃, H₂SO₄
Higher H⁺ concentration = lower pH.

questions.prompt: What is a weak acid?
correctAnswers: acid that partially ionises to form H+ ions

feedback.correct: Perfect! Weak acids only partially ionise.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! In weak acids, only SOME molecules split into ions. Is this complete or partial ionisation?

revisionFacts: Weak acid = partially ionises in water.
Examples: ethanoic acid, citric acid, carbonic acid
Lower H⁺ concentration than strong acid of same concentration.

questions.prompt: What happens to H⁺ ion concentration when pH decreases by 1?

feedback.correct: Exactly! pH is a logarithmic scale.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! pH is logarithmic. Each pH unit is a factor of 10. If pH drops by 1, does H⁺ concentration ×2, ×10, or ×100?

revisionFacts: pH decrease of 1 = H⁺ concentration × 10
pH increase of 1 = H⁺ concentration ÷ 10
pH is a logarithmic scale (base 10).

questions.prompt: Complete the half equation: Na → _____

feedback.correct: Perfect! Sodium loses 1 electron to form Na⁺.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Na has 1 outer electron. To become Na⁺, does it gain or lose that electron? Show this with e⁻.

revisionFacts: Na → Na⁺ + e⁻ (oxidation - loss of electrons)
Group 1 metals form +1 ions.
This is why sodium is so reactive.

questions.prompt: Complete the half equation: Mg → _____

feedback.correct: Excellent! Magnesium loses 2 electrons to form Mg²⁺.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Mg is in Group 2, so has 2 outer electrons. To become Mg²⁺, how many e⁻ must it lose?

revisionFacts: Mg → Mg²⁺ + 2e⁻ (oxidation - loss of 2 electrons)
Group 2 metals form +2 ions.
Need to lose 2 electrons to get full outer shell.

questions.prompt: What does OILRIG stand for?
correctAnswers: oxidation is loss reduction is gain
oxidation is loss, reduction is gain
OIL RIG: oxidation is loss, reduction is gain

feedback.correct: Perfect memory aid! Use this for all redox questions.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! It's a memory trick: OIL RIG. What does each part stand for?

revisionFacts: OILRIG = Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain (of electrons)
Essential for understanding redox reactions.
Loss/gain refers to electrons, not oxygen.

questions.prompt: Which properties are common to Group 1 metals? (Select all that apply)
options: Soft and can be cut with a knife
correctAnswers: Soft and can be cut with a knife

feedback.correct: Excellent! You know the key properties of alkali metals.
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Remember: Group 1 metals are soft, shiny when fresh, and good conductors - but they have LOW melting points for metals.

revisionFacts: Group 1 metals are soft (can be cut with knife).
They're shiny when freshly cut but tarnish quickly in air.
Good conductors of heat and electricity (like all metals).

questions.prompt: Which reactions produce water as a product? (Select all that apply)

feedback.correct: Perfect! You know which acid reactions produce water!
feedback.incorrect: Good thinking! Remember: neutralisation reactions (acid + alkali/base) produce water. Metal + acid produces hydrogen gas instead.

revisionFacts: Acid + alkali/base → salt + water (neutralisation)
Acid + metal carbonate → salt + water + CO₂
Metal + acid → salt + hydrogen (NOT water!)

questions.prompt: Which metals need electrolysis to extract them? (Select all that apply)

feedback.correct: Brilliant! You know which metals are too reactive for carbon reduction!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Metals MORE reactive than carbon need electrolysis: K, Na, Li, Ca, Mg, Al.

revisionFacts: Metals above carbon need electrolysis: K, Na, Li, Ca, Mg, Al
Metals below carbon can use reduction: Zn, Fe, Cu
More reactive = harder (more expensive) to extract

questions.prompt: Order these metals from MOST to LEAST reactive:

feedback.correct: Perfect knowledge of the reactivity series!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Remember: Ca > Mg > (Al > C > Zn >) Fe > (H >) Cu

revisionFacts: Reactivity series: K, Na, Li, Ca, Mg, (C), Zn, Fe, (H), Cu, Ag, Au
Learn it with a mnemonic or by finding them on periodic table
More reactive = loses electrons more easily

questions.prompt: Order these halogens from LIGHTEST to DARKEST colour:

feedback.correct: Excellent! You know your halogen colours!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Colours get darker down the group: Cl₂ (pale green) → Br₂ (red-brown) → I₂ (grey/purple)

revisionFacts: Chlorine: pale green/yellow gas
Bromine: red-brown liquid
Iodine: dark grey solid (purple vapour)

questions.prompt: Order these noble gases from LOWEST to HIGHEST boiling point:

feedback.correct: Spot on! Boiling points increase down Group 0!
feedback.incorrect: Good thinking! Boiling points increase down Group 0 as atoms get bigger and heavier.

revisionFacts: Noble gas boiling points increase down the group
This is due to increasing atomic mass
Helium has the lowest boiling point of all elements!

questions.prompt: Match each acid to the salt it produces:

feedback.correct: Perfect matching! You know which acids make which salts!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Remember: the acid name tells you the salt name - hydrochloric → chloride, sulfuric → sulfate, nitric → nitrate.

revisionFacts: Acid name → salt name pattern
Hydrochloric acid (HCl) → chloride salts
Sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) → sulfate salts
Nitric acid (HNO₃) → nitrate salts

questions.prompt: Match each metal to its typical ion charge:

feedback.correct: Brilliant! You know your ion charges!
feedback.incorrect: Good effort! Hint: Group 1 = +1, Group 2 = +2, Group 3 (Al) = +3.

revisionFacts: Group 1 metals form +1 ions (lose 1 electron)
Group 2 metals form +2 ions (lose 2 electrons)
Aluminium (Group 3) forms +3 ions
Transition metals can form different charges (Fe²⁺ or Fe³⁺)

questions.prompt: Match each gas to its test observation:

feedback.correct: Perfect! You know all your gas tests!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! Remember: hydrogen = squeaky pop, oxygen = relights glowing splint, CO₂ = limewater milky.

revisionFacts: Hydrogen: lit splint → squeaky pop
Oxygen: glowing splint → relights
Carbon dioxide: limewater → turns milky/cloudy

questions.prompt: Match each process to its definition:

pairs.right: More reactive metal replaces less reactive
Acid reacts with base to form salt and water

feedback.correct: Excellent understanding of key chemistry processes!
feedback.incorrect: Good thinking! Remember OILRIG for redox, and think about reactivity for displacement.

revisionFacts: OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain (of electrons)
Displacement: more reactive displaces less reactive
Neutralisation: acid + base → salt + water

questions.prompt: True or False: Metals at the top of the reactivity series are the most reactive.

feedback.correct: Correct! Potassium is at the top and is very reactive!
feedback.incorrect: Good try! The reactivity series goes from most reactive (top) to least reactive (bottom).

revisionFacts: Reactivity series: most reactive at top, least at bottom

questions.prompt: True or False: Electrolysis is more expensive than reduction with carbon.

feedback.correct: Yes! Electrolysis needs continuous electricity which is very expensive.
feedback.incorrect: Good thinking! Actually, electrolysis is much more expensive - it needs lots of electrical energy.

revisionFacts: Electrolysis is very expensive (continuous electricity)
Carbon reduction is much cheaper (just heat)
This is why aluminium used to be very valuable
